The "National Security Sealift Enhancement Act of 1999" includes provisions for capital construction funds, election to expense US flag vessels, income exclusion for merchant seamen, and exemption from alternative minimum tax. Sec. 401 exempts corporations operating US flag vessels from alternative minimum tax. TITLE V discusses conventions on US-flag cruise ships. The definition of a "qualified withdrawal" in section 7518 of the Internal Revenue Code is clarified to include amounts in funds as of a specific date. The term "eligible vessel" is also defined as a vessel documented under US laws and operated domestically or internationally. The term "qualified vessel" refers to a vessel constructed or reconstructed in the United States, documented under US laws, and intended to be operated in US fisheries or foreign trade. The term "vessel" includes containers, trailers, and cargo handling equipment intended for use on eligible vessels, as well as ocean-going towing vessels and barges operated on the Great Lakes. "Foreign commerce" and "foreign trade" refer to trade activities outside the United States. The term "commerce" and "foreign trade" are defined in section 905 of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936, to include trade between foreign ports. A "qualified lease" is a lease with a term of at least 5 years. SEC. 102 of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to allow the deposit of duty into a Capital Construction Fund for eligible vessels instead of paying the Secretary of the Treasury directly. This amendment is effective immediately. Additionally, there is an election to expense certain United States flag vessels. SEC. 201. ELECTION TO EXPENSE CERTAIN UNITED STATES FLAG VESSELS. Amended by inserting new section: "SEC. 179B. DEDUCTION FOR UNITED STATES FLAG VESSELS." A taxpayer can elect to treat the cost of a qualified United States flag vessel as an expense not chargeable to its capital account. The deduction is allowed in the year the vessel becomes qualified, defined as a US flag vessel operated exclusively in the foreign trade of the US. The cost is the lesser of the purchase price or adjusted basis of the vessel. The adjusted basis of a qualified United States flag vessel is determined under section 1011. The basis of any property is reduced by the cost taken into account. Section 911 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include certain merchant marine crews as qualified individuals for tax purposes, regardless of the usual requirements. The amendment treats income earned by merchant seamen on vessels engaged in transportation between the US and a foreign country as foreign earned income. Effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. TITLE IV--EXEMPTION FROM ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX

SEC. 401. Exemption from alternative minimum tax for corporations operating US flag vessels. Section 55 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide an exemption for corporations operating United States flag vessels. The tentative minimum tax of a corporation will be zero for any taxable year if the corporation is a qualified corporation, meaning it is a domestic corporation with assets related to the maritime transportation business and owns or charters a fleet of 4 or more qualified United States flag vessels. The amendment defines a qualified United States flag vessel as one with a deadweight tonnage of at least 10,000 tons operated exclusively in the foreign trade of the United States. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 501 amends the Internal Revenue Code to specify that a cruise ship must be registered in the United States. This amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
